Article Enhanced conversion of lignin into mono-cycloalkanes via C–C bonds cleavage over multifunctional Pt-Nb/MOR catalyst Zhiruo Guo Xiaohui Liu Yong Guo Yanqin Wang * State Key Laboratory of Green Chemical Engineering and Industrial Catalysis, Research Institute of Industrial Catalysis, School of Chemistry and Molecular Engineering, East China University of Science and Technology, Shanghai 200237, China State Key Laboratory of Green Chemical Engineering and Industrial Catalysis Research Institute of Industrial Catalysis School of Chemistry and Molecular Engineering East China University of Science and Technology Shanghai 200237 China State Key Laboratory of Green Chemical Engineering and Industrial Catalysis, Research Institute of Industrial Catalysis, School of Chemistry and Molecular Engineering, East China University of Science and Technology, Shanghai 200237, China * Corresponding author. The efficient conversion of lignin into mono-cycloalkanes via both C–O and C–C bonds cleavage are attractive, but challenging due to the high C–C bond dissociation energy. Previous studies have demonstrated that NbO x -based catalysts exhibited exceptional capabilities for CAr–C bond cleavage and broken the limitation of lignin monomers. In this work, we presented an economical multifunctional Pt-Nb/MOR catalyst that achieved an impressive monomer yield of 147% during the depolymerization and hydrodeoxygenation of lignin into mono-cycloalkanes. Reaction pathway studies showed that unlike traditional NbO x -based catalytic system, bicyclohexane was an important intermediate in this system and followed the C sp3–C sp3 cleavage pathway after complete cyclic-hydrogenation. Deep investigations demonstrated that the doping of Nb in Pt/MOR not only enhanced the activation of hydrogen by Pt, but also increased the acidity of MOR, both of these are favor for the hydrogenolytic cleavage of C sp3–C sp3 bonds. This work provides a low-cost catalyst to obtain high-yield monomers from lignin under relatively mild conditions and would help to design catalysts with higher activity for the valorization of lignin. Graphical Abstract An economical multifunctional Pt-Nb/MOR catalyst was designed in this work to enhanced the conversion of lignin into mono-cycloalkanes (147%) under mild conditions. Unlike previous works, a C sp3–C sp3 bond cleavage pathway was found to be the main one in this work. Interaction between Pt and Nb was the key to achieving high activity. Keywords Lignin Mono-cycloalkanes C–C bond cleavage Pt-Nb/MOR catalyst 1 Introduction Lignin is currently receiving increased attention for its status as the most abundant renewable aromatic carbon resource [1–3]. It is composed of sinapyl alcohol(S), coniferyl alcohol (G), and p-coumaryl alcohol (H) monomers [4–6]. These monomers form a three-dimensional network linked by approximately 70% C–O bonds (β–O–4, α–O–4, and 4–O–5) and 30% C–C bonds (such as 5–5, β–5’, and β–β’) [7]. The effective cleavage of these bonds is crucial for lignin depolymerization and upgrading to value-added products [8]. Efficient transformation of lignin, which generates phenolics [9,10], aromatic hydrocarbons [11–13], and cycloalkanes [11,14,15], is currently receiving widespread attention. For the hydrogenolysis of C–O bonds, extensive researches have been conducted, including the cleavage of C–O bond linkage and C–O bond on benzene ring (Ph-OH and Ph-OCH3) [2,6,16,17]. For example, Li et al. [18] successfully achieved switchable selectivity of high-yield aromatic monomers (36.2 wt%–59.2 wt%) by adjusting the ratio of hydrogen donor/acceptor with C–O bonds cleavage on Ru/C catalysts. Our group [19] demonstrated that Ru/Nb2O5 catalyst was high active toward the cleavage of C–O bonds in lignin and exhibited remarkable selectivity to monocyclic aromatic hydrocarbons under H2 atmosphere. A series of deep investigations showed the influences of Ru particle sizes and the coordination states of Nb2O5 on the activity and selectivity in C–O bond cleavage [20–24]. Hydrogen-free conversion was a promising strategy and a Pt/NiAl2O4 catalyst showed remarkable catalytic activity, which can convert birch lignin into 4-alkyl phenols (17.3 wt% yield) in a one-pot process [25] by using structural H in lignin. Furthermore, the cleavage of C–O linkages in lignin was successfully achieved and resulted in a 46.6 wt% monomer yield of phenolics with cellulose intact through a self-hydrogen supplied catalytic fractionation (SCF) strategy over Pt/NiAl2O4 [26]. Although the above works for lignin C–O bond cleavage into monomers have achieved remarkable progress, there are still 25%–30% of oligomers linked by C–C bonds in lignin depolymerized products [27]. If this part of oligomers can be depolymerized to monomer, the monomer yield of lignin will be further improved. Compared to C–O bonds (209–348 kJ/mol), the cleavage of C–C bonds (226–494 kJ/mol) presents greater challenges due to their higher bond energy [1,28], which considerably limits the effective utilization of lignin. At present, a series of efforts for lignin C–C bond cleavage have been done to solve this issue. For example, Shuai et al. [29] proposed the utilization of CoS2 to facilitate the cleavage of β–1 bond in the model compound under mild conditions, achieving an impressive yield of 88% phenolic monomers. Hβ zeolite was used by Kong et al. [30] to achieve an increase in total phenolic monomer yield by 59%–102% during the depolymerization of industrial condensed lignin in water (mainly cleavage α–1 bonds). Nevertheless, the cleavage of the strongest 5–5’ bond in natural lignin still difficult in these works. To solve this problem, the remarkable NbO x -based catalysts in cleaving C–C bonds within lignin garnered significant attention. In our previous work [31], the Ru/NbOPO4 catalyst effectively integrated the advantages of NbO x -based material for C–O bonds activation and Brönsted acid sites for C–C bonds activation, resulting in a remarkable monomer molar yield of 153% from Kraft lignin at 310 °C. The cleavage of the C–C bonds in this study predominantly relies on the formation of Csp2–Csp3 intermediates, and the monomers were obtained by C sp2–C sp3 cleavage at the Brönsted acid sites of the NbO x -based catalyst. Cao et al. [32] developed porous Pt/Nb2WO8 catalysts that effectively cleave C–O and C–C bonds (including 5–5’ bonds) in lignin, resulting in a production of 49.08% alkyl-benzene monomers at 300 °C, 1.5 MPa H2. The synergistic interaction between Pt and W/Nb was crucial for achieving high catalytic activity. Recently, Luo et al. [33] also realized the C–C bond cleavage of oligomers in lignin oil by using cheaper zeolite catalyst (Pt/MOR). The lignin oil (monomers + oligomers) was first produced through reductive catalytic fractionation (RCF) process, then further depolymerized oligomers and obtained the mono-cycloalkanes, the monomer yield was improved from 42.3% (RCF step) to 76.9% at 300 °C, 40 bar H2. A pathway via C sp3–C sp3 intermediates was proposed, accompanied with the C sp2–C sp3 cleavage. This work provides an idea for designing more economical catalysts for C–C cleavage by using the acid sites of zeolite. In this work, we take the advantages of NbO x -based catalysts and zeolite catalysts together and prepared a new Pt-Nb/MOR catalyst featuring lower costs and higher catalytic activity under milder conditions. The one-pot transformation of lignin to alkylcyclohexanes monomers was realized at 300 °C, 0.5 MPa H2, the yield of monomers reached 147%. The activation of hydrogen species by metallic Pt sites [34,35] and the cleavages of C–O, C–C bonds facilitated by Nb-modified MOR were synergistically integrated within multifunctional Pt-Nb/MOR catalyst. Reaction mechanism was studied by using a 5–5’ model compound, o-Phenyl Phenol. By capturing the intermediates, a different C–C cleavage pathway from our previous NbO x -based catalysts was demonstrated: o-Phenyl Phenol was mostly hydrogenated to bicyclohexane by the Pt site, then the C sp3–C sp3 bonds were cleaved under the synergistic effect of Pt and NbO x , reaching a monomer yield of 75.8%. Due to the addition of NbO x , Pt species in Pt-Nb/MOR catalyst existed in a more metallic state and performed better in activating hydrogen than that of Pt/MOR. In addition, NbO x species in catalysts increased the acidity of the catalyst and played an important role in C–C bond cleavage [31]. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation 2Pt2Nb/MOR: Nb-doped MOR was prepared by grinding commercially hydrated niobium oxalate (98%, Meryer (Shanghai) Chemical Technology Co., Ltd.) with Zeolite MOR (Adamas-beta, Shanghai Titan Scientific Co., Ltd.), followed by calcining in Muffle furnace at a heating rate of 2 °C/min to 500 °C and then hold for 3 h to obtain yNb/MOR (y = 1, 2, 5, 10, Nb wt%). Pt was loaded on Nb/MOR via the incipient wetness impregnation method, by using an aqueous solution of 0.15 g/mL Pt(NO3)2. After drying at 100 °C for 6 h, the catalyst was calcined at 400 °C (5 °C/min) in Muffle furnace for 3 h to remove nitrate and obtain xPt-yNb/MOR (x = 0.5, 1, 2, Pt wt%) samples. Preparation of other Pt-Nb/zeolite catalysts were the same as above. 2Pt/MOR was synthesized by directly impregnating Pt(NO3)2 with a mass fraction of 2% Pt on MOR and then the catalyst was calcined at 400 °C with 5 °C/min in Muffle furnace for 3 h. 2Pt/Nb2O5 catalyst and 2Pt/NbOPO4 catalyst were also prepared by incipient wetness impregnation method, followed by calcining at 400 °C for 3 h in Muffle furnace. The preparation methods for Nb2O5 and NbOPO4 were mentioned in our previous report [19,31]. 2Pt-2Nb/MOR(I) was prepared by two-step impregnation. First, niobium oxalate solution (0.4 mol/L Nb) was used to drop Nb on the support MOR, followed by calcining in Muffle furnace at a heating rate of 2 °C/min to 500 °C and then hold for 3 h to obtain 2Nb/MOR. Pt was loaded on Nb/MOR via the incipient wetness impregnation method, drying 6 h at 100 °C and then calcining at 400 °C in Muffle furnace for 3 h to get 2Pt-2Nb/MOR(I). 2Pt-2Nb/MOR(H) was prepared by hydrothermal method [36,37]. 0.63 g NaAlO2 (1.0 eq, 99.0%, Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd) was added into 10 mL 1.5 mol/L NaOH (aq). After the solid was completely dissolved, niobium oxalate solution (0.4 mol/L Nb) and 0.6 g CTAB were introduced into the solution, stirring at room temperature for 1 h. After that, 15.0 eq. SiO2 (99.9%, Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd) was added into the solution under room temperature, stirring at room temperature for another 1 h. Then the aqueous solution was transferred into a 100-mL teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 170 °C for 24 h. After reaction, the white precipitates were filtered, washed with deionized water until pH < 10 and dried at 100 °C overnight. After drying, the sample was dispersed in 20 mL 1.5 mol/L NH4NO3 solution and ion-exchanged for 2 h at 80 °C. Then the sample was washed and collected by centrifugation, dried at 100 °C overnight. Finally, the dried white powders were calcined at 550 °C for 6 h in air with a heating rate of 2 °C/min. The loading of Pt was same as above. All catalysts were reduced for 2 h at 400 °C (5 °C/min) in 10% H2/Ar and swept in a pure N2 atmosphere to room temperature and then hold for 30 min before use. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on a Rigaku D/max2550VB/PC diffractometer with Cu Kα (λ = 0.15406 nm) radiation and the transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were taken on a FEI Tecnai F20s-TWIN instrument with the electron-beam accelerating voltage was 200 kV. Nitrogen adsorption and desorption analysis was carried out on ASAP 2020M Instrument at liquid nitrogen temperature (–196 °C). The surface area was calculated by using the Brumauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method and the pore size distribution was obtained by using the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. The contents of metal over supports were all measured by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES) on an Agilent 725ED ICP-AES manufactured by Agilent Technologies, USA. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were recorded on a Thermo Scientific Escalab 250 Xi system with monochromatic Al Kα radiation and all results were calibrated using the C 1s peak at 284.8 eV. In situ CO diffused reflectance Fourier transformed infrared (CO-DRIFT) studies were carried out in a reaction chamber (Harreck) and recorded by using a Nicolet NEXUS 670 FTIR spectrometer. Firstly, the catalysts were reduced at 400 °C for 1 h in a 10% H2/Ar mixture. After the temperature was dropped to 50 °C, probe molecules CO were introduced, then a continuous Ar flow was used to sweep the physically-adsorbed molecules. The band signals were obtained by subtracting the IR background. IR spectra of pyridine adsorption were also recorded on a Nicolet NEXUS 670 FTIR spectrometer. Samples not exceeding 20 mg were accurately weighed and compressed into sheets. The simples were dehydrated by heating at 400 °C for 1 h under vacuum before each test. After the sample chamber was cooled to 100 °C, the IR spectrum was recorded as a background. After cooling to 50 °C, pyridine vapor was introduced into the sample chamber until equilibrium was reached. Finally, the temperature was raised to 100 °C and the second spectrum was recorded. The spectra presented were obtained by subtracting the spectra recorded before and after pyridine adsorption. 2.3 Catalytic performance and products analysis The catalyst performance was performed in a 50-mL stainless-steel batch reactor. Before each test, the reactor was loaded by 50 mg catalysts (0.2 g for lignin), 1.3 mmol substrate (or 0.2 g lignin) and 5 mL octane. The reactor was flushed with pure H2 to remove air, and then maintained the initial pressure at 0.5 MPa. After that, the reactor was rapidly heated to the target temperature and reacted for designed times. After reaction, the reactor was quickly cooled to room temperature and 100 μL of paraxylene was added as the internal standard (100 μL tridecane for lignin). After centrifugation, the liquid phase product was obtained and analyzed by GC-MS (Agilent 7890A-5975C), GC (Agilent 7890B) and HPLC (Agilent 1200 Series). The conversion and yield were calculated by the following formulas, in which Eqs. (1) and (2) are calculated when the model compound was the substrate, and Eqs. (3) and (4) were calculated when lignin was the substrate. The reactions were repeated twice and the error was no more than 5%. Conversion of model compound (%) = (1) m o l e s o f s u b s t r a t e a f t e r r e a c t i o n m o l e s o f s u b s t r a t e b e f o r e r e a c t i o n × 100 % Yield of model compound reaction (%) = (2) m o l e s o f o n e p r o d u c t a f t e r r e a c t i o n m o l e s o f s u b s t r a t e t o t a l l y c o n v e r t e d t o p r o d u c t × 100 % (3) Mass Yields of monomers ( % ) = m a s s o f m o n o m e r p r o d u c t m a s s o f l i g n i n × 100 % Molar yield of monomers (%) = (4) m o l e s o f m o n o m e r p r o d u c t m a s s o f l i g n i n m o n o m e r s m e a s u r e d b y N B O m e t h o d × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Screening catalyst for the catalytic cleavage of C–C bond in lignin model compounds In natural lignin, 5–5’ bond constitutes the highest proportion among all C–C linkages and has the dissociation energy of 481–494 kJ/mol [1,6]. Therefore, o-phenyl phenol (1) with 5–5’ linkage was chosen as the model compound to screen catalysts. In order to compare the catalytic activity among investigated catalysts and detect the possible intermediates, the reaction was carried out under relatively mild conditions (260 °C and 0.5 MPa H2). Firstly, the catalytic performance of several 2Pt-2Nb/zeolite catalysts were investigated and compared (Table 1 ). The main product over all zeolite catalysts was cyclohexane (6) with the yield in order: 2Pt-2Nb/MOR > 2Pt-2Nb/β40 > 2Pt-2Nb/β25 > 2Pt-2Nb/ZSM-5 > 2Pt-2Nb/USY (Table 1, entries 1–5). The most active 2Pt-2Nb/MOR catalyst resulted in a 48.2% yield of cyclohexane (6) and the least one over 2Pt-2Nb/USY was 18.4%. Among these catalysts, the conversion over 2Pt-2Nb/ZSM-5 and 2Pt-2Nb/USY were unsatisfactory, only 56.1% and 78.1%, respectively, with intermediates, such as biphenyl (2), phenyl-cyclohexane (3), bicyclohexane (4) and the rearranged product dimethylnaphthalene (9) being detected, indicating the poor activity in C–C bond cleavage. In contrast, the conversion over other catalysts was all 99.9%. As comparison, the previously investigated NbO x -based catalysts were also tested and found the conversion of o-Phenyl Phenol (1) over 2Pt/Nb2O5 and 2Pt/NbOPO4 were both 99.9% (Table 1, entries 6, 7), indicating their high activity. However, more intermediates, such as phenyl-cyclohexane (3) and bicyclohexane (4) were left, leading to a lower cyclohexane (6) and total monomer yields (29.3%/43.2% over 2Pt/Nb2O5 and 37.1%/50.5% over 2Pt/NbOPO4) than those over 2Pt-2Nb/MOR catalyst (48.2%/75.8%). Thus, it was encouraged us to replace the previously developed NbO x -based catalysts by the cheaper and more active Nb-modified MOR zeolite catalyst and investigate the catalytic mechanism. Then the effect of Nb and Pt contents on catalyst performance was investigated and the results were collected in Table 2 . Since the support were all MOR zeolite, it was omitted in the subsequent description, for example, 2Pt-2Nb/MOR was shortened to 2Pt-2Nb. When fixing the Pt content at 2 wt% and increasing Nb content (1 wt%, 2 wt%, 5 wt%, 10 wt%), the conversion of o-Phenyl Phenol (1) remained at 99.9%, while the monomer yield showed a volcanic curve (Table 2, entries 1–5). Over 2Pt catalyst, the monomer yield was 32.7%, with 20.7% of cyclohexane (6) as the main product. Concurrently, 60.9% of various bicyclic-products were left in the system, indicating its poor activity for C–C cleavage. When 1 wt% Nb was added into the catalyst (2Pt-1Nb), the total monomer yield reached 52.5%, and yield of the main product cyclohexane (6) was 33.4%. Over 2Pt-2Nb catalyst, the monomer yield reached 75.8% (48.2% of cyclohexane 6, 8.5% of benzene 7, and 19.1% of methylcyclopentane 8), demonstrated a significant increase in C–C bond cleavage. When increasing Nb content further to 5 wt% and 10% (2Pt-5Nb, 2Pt-10Nb), the monomer yield is surprisingly decreased from 75.8% to 52.8% and 49.6%, respectively. It was worth noting that 17.6% of bicyclohexane (4) and the isomerization products ((cyclopentylmethyl)cyclohexane (5), 13.0% + dimethylnaphthalene (9), 7.1%) were present over 2Pt-5Nb (Table 2 entry 4). While, there were not only more dimethylnaphthalene (9, 15.7%) existed over 2Pt-10Nb, but also large intermediates [phenyl-cyclohexane (3) in 13.0% and bicyclohexane (4) in 12.6%] were present (Table 2 entry 5). These results indicated that the doping of Nb indeed enhanced the ability for C–C bond cleavage; while excessive content of Nb might facilitate the isomerization of intermediate, bicyclohexane (4) into dimethylnaphthalene (9), which hindered the further hydrogenolysis of C–C bond. Therefore, it was essential to limit the Nb content, with 2 wt% as optimal. Following the assessment of Nb content, the Pt content was subsequently decreased to attain a more economical catalyst. However, the results were not satisfactory. As the Pt content decreased, the conversion of the substrate o-Phenyl Phenol (1) was decreased and the conversion was only 25.0% without Pt loading (Table 2, entries 1, 6–8). The intermediates of biphenyl (2) and phenyl-cyclohexane (3) were abundant in this system, indicating the importance of Pt species. Previous studies have shown that noble metals have the ability to activate hydrogen and benzene ring hydrogenation [38,39], and currently the break of 5–5’ bond requires aromatic ring hydrogenation as an initiation step. So metallic Pt in this system might play a crucial role in the catalytic reaction to activate hydrogen and ring hydrogenation, and the reduction of its content will inevitably affect the reaction activity. The catalytic performance of 2Pt-2Nb/MOR catalysts prepared by different methods was also compared in Table S1. When 2Pt-2Nb/MOR(I) was used, total monomer yield was 47.1% (22.0% of cyclohexane 6, 5.5% of benzene 7, and 4.4% of methylcyclopentane 8), and as for 2Pt-2Nb/MOR(H), total monomer yield was 44.9% (28.1% of cyclohexane 6, 10.8% of benzene 7, and 9.5% of methylcyclopentane 8). The catalytic performance of C–C bond cleavage over these two catalysts is no better than the catalyst prepared by grinding. Ultimately, 2Pt-2Nb was chosen for further investigation owing to its superior C–C cracking performance. 3.2 Reaction pathway studies on lignin model compounds The reaction pathways of the model compound, o-Phenyl Phenol (1) over the 2Pt-2Nb catalyst were examined at 260 °C and the time course profiles were presented in the Fig. 1 . Within the first 0.5 h of the reaction, 62.1% of o-Phenyl Phenol (1) were rapidly transformed to 7.7% of biphenyl (2) and 39.2% of phenyl-cyclohexane (3) by hydrodeoxygenation and partial hydrogenation of aromatic rings. Only 2.9% of bicyclohexane (4) and 2.7% of monomers were detected. After a 1-hour reaction, the conversion of o-Phenyl Phenol (1) reached 99.9%, with biphenyl (2) no longer being detected and the intermediate phenyl-cyclohexane (3) in the system was decreased to 19.8%. Concurrently, a significant amount of bicyclohexane (4) (72.1%) was identified in the system, along with a minor presence of isomer (cyclopentylmethyl)cyclohexane (5) at 2.1%. The yield of monomers within the system reached to 3.8%. When the reaction time was prolonged to 4 hours, bicyclohexane (4) was decreased to 40.7%, while the total monomer yield increased to 31.1%. The content of intermediate (cyclopentylmethyl)cyclohexane (5) initially increased and subsequently decreased with the extension of reaction time, reaching a peak of 16.7% at 3 h, then declining to 12.2% at 4 h. This result showed that C–C bonds cleavage of (cyclopentylmethyl)cyclohexane (5) was also possible to form monomers. Following an additional 4-h reaction period (8 h in total), bicyclohexane (4) and (cyclopentylmethyl)cyclohexane (5) was further decreased. Concurrently, the yield of the monomers increased to 52.7% (38.7% of cyclohexane 6, 6.8% of benzene 7 and 17.2% of methylcyclopentane 8). After 16 h of reaction, bicyclohexane (4) was completely consumed, resulting in a total monomer yield of 93.7% (57.1% of cyclohexane 6, 7.1% of benzene 7 and 29.5% of methylcyclopentane 8), with a minor of side product dimethylnaphthalene (9, 3.6%) in the system. The above results showed that C–C bonds in substrate o-Phenyl Phenol (1) could be cleaved through intermediates phenyl-cyclohexane (3), bicyclohexane (4) and (cyclopentylmethyl)cyclohexane (5), and bicyclohexane (4) was the most important intermediate in this system. It was clear that the cleavage of the C–C bond in bicyclohexane (4) constituted a significant challenge, and this step could potentially serve as the rate-determining step for the overall reaction. In previous studies, the formation of phenyl-cyclohexane (3) with C sp2–C sp3 was considered to be the key intermediate for 5–5’ bond cleavage [31,33], while here the cleavage of bicyclohexane (4) with C sp3–C sp3 in this study appeared to dominate the system. In order to confirm that the cleavage path of 5–5’ bond on 2Pt-2Nb catalyst was indeed different from that of previous NbO x -based catalysts, phenyl-cyclohexane (3) and bicyclohexane (4) were selected as substrates for reactivity tests, respectively. Fig. 2 showed the catalytic performance when using phenyl-cyclohexane (3) as substrate. 34.3% of the monomers were obtained on 2Pt-2Nb with benzene (7) being proven by HPLC, which confirmed that the traditional C sp2–C sp3 cleavage pathway still existed in this work, although not as higher as over Pt/Nb2O5 and Pt/NbOPO4 catalysts. At the same time, 43.5% of intermediate 4 were detected, suggesting that there may be a different main reaction pathway on 2Pt-2Nb. When bicyclohexane (4) was used as substrate, the reaction results on various catalysts were shown in Fig. 3 . Consistent with our general recognition, the conversion of substrate bicyclohexane (4) on 2Pt/Nb2O5 was low, only 32.9%. Meanwhile, 19.1% of (cyclopentylmethyl)cyclohexane (5) and 8.7% of dimethylnaphthalene (9) were generated through the isomerization of bicyclohexane over this catalyst, and only 0.8% of monomers were detected. On 2Pt/NbOPO4, the conversion of bicyclohexane (4) was 30.6% and the monomer yield was also low, only 1.3%, in agreement with our previous works. However, the results on 2Pt-2Nb were quite different, a conversion of 44.1% and 22.7% yield of monomers were realized. When the reaction time was shortened to 30 min, another intermediate 1-cyclohexyl-1-cyclohexene (10, 1.5%) was detected, hint that bicyclohexane (4) had the potential to break the C–C bond by forming intermediate 1-cyclohexyl-1-cyclohexene (10). As mentioned above, the absence of NbO x component in 2Pt leads to decreased activity, 38.2% conversion of bicyclohexane and 0.5% monomer yield was detected on 2Pt, with the isomerization product dimethylnaphthalene (9) as the main product (34.6%). As for 2Nb catalyst, the conversion was only 25.1%, and the monomer yield was 0.6%. In summary, the mainly reaction pathway for cracking 5–5’ bond in this work was different from that of traditional Nb-based catalysts. After obtaining bicyclohexane 4 by deep hydrogenation, C sp3–C sp3 bond could be cracked to obtain high-yield monomer products (Scheme 1 , Path A) and the synergistic effect of Pt-Nb was crucial for attaining this high activity. Bicyclohexane (4) also can be isomerized to (cyclopentylmethyl)cyclohexane (5) and then cleaved to cyclohexane and methyl-cyclopentane monomers (Scheme 1, Path C), and the traditional C sp2–C sp3 cleavage pathway still existed (Scheme 1, Path B). Subsequently, we performed substrate expansion of the model compounds utilizing 2Pt-2Nb to investigate the general applicability (Fig. 4, Fig. S3). A conversion of 99.9% was detected on substrate 1a and 1b, with the total monomer yield and cyclohexane yield are similar (71% total monomer yield and 53% cyclohexane yield). It was evident that hydroxyl substitution at the 5–5’ ortho-position had not effect on the reactivity. When the hydroxyl group on para-position (1c), the conversion still achieved 99.9%, while the monomer yield was decreased to 65.8%, with 35% of bicyclohexane remaining unreacted. In this system, the cleavage of the C–C bond in ortho-substituent-containing substrates with lower C–C barriers for 5–5’ breaking was more facile compared to that in para-substituent-containing substrates, which was consistent with the conclusions reported in the previous literature [40]. When using β-1 model compound 1d as substrate, the conversion was 65.3% and the total monomer yield was 39.5%, and the absence of oxygen-containing substituents in aromatic rings may be the cause of the relatively low activity [33,40]_ENREF_38. When the reaction time was extended to 24 h, the conversion became 99.9%, with 70.3% monomer yield. Among the monomers from β-1 model compound 1d, the yield of methylcyclohexane was the highest [29.0% (12 h), 50.4% (24 h)]. In our previous studies [31], more benzene/cyclohexane and ethylbenzene/ethyl-cyclohexane were generated after the decomposition of the β-1 model compound following the C sp2–C sp3 cleavage mechanism, but here the formation of a large amount of methylcyclohexane in this system once again confirmed the C sp3–C sp3-dominated cleavage pathway over 2Pt-2Nb. As for the diphenylmethane (1e), 86.8% substrate conversion and 69.8% monomers were obtained after 12 h. Extending the reaction time to 24 h, the conversion became 99.9%, with 84.6% monomer yield. Due to the large amount of methoxy in the lignin structure, model compounds containing methoxy were also used as substrates (Fig. 4 1f–1i) to test the catalytic performance of 2Pt-2Nb. When the methoxy group was located in the ortho-position (1f) and para-position (1h) of the 5–5’ bond, the monomer yield can reach 76.3% and 87.9%, respectively, while when the methoxy group was located in the intermediate position (1g), the monomer yield was slightly reduced to 55.2%. When there were two methoxy groups in the substrate (1i), the conversion was only 55.2% and the monomer yield was only 13.7% after 12 h. The presence of 0.8% of anisole and 2.1% of 2-cyclohexylanisole (Fig. S3) also confirmed the existence of the C sp3–C sp2 cleavage pathway. When the reaction time was extended to 24 h, the substrate was completely transformed and the monomer yield reached 84.3%. In summary, 2Pt-2Nb catalyst in this work had good universality and can obtain ideal monomer yield on most model compounds containing C–C bond. 3.3 Catalytic performance of 2Pt-2Nb in the transformation of Lignin Finally, oganosolv birch lignin (Note S1) [41] was used as a substrate to assess reaction activity over 2Pt-2Nb catalyst at 300 °C, 0.5 MPa H2 and a mass yield of 32.1 wt% was achieved, with a molar yield of 147.3% (Fig. 5 ). This result was comparable to that obtained over 2Pt/NbOPO4 (30.9 wt% and 141.3%). When the catalyst was applied to commercial alkali lignin, Kraft lignin and enzymatic hydrolysis lignin, the monomer mass yields of 22.9 wt%, 30.2 wt% and 24.7 wt%, and the monomer molar yields of 258.2%, 171.5% and 165.5% were obtained, respectively. Among all lignin, birch lignin owns the highest monomer content 2540 μmol/g measured by NBO method (Note S2) [27,42], which may be the reason for its high monomer yield (Table S2). Alkali lignin resulted in lower mass yield and lower NBO monomer content (225 μmol/g, Table S2). This may due to the presence of S element (Table S3) and some possible inorganic salt components, resulting in a high molar yield of alkali lignin. The above results indicate the super activity of 2Pt-2Nb catalyst in C–O bond cleavage and C–C cracking across various types of lignin. For comparison, several reported works on lignin C–C cleavage to monomers were summarized in Table S4. It can be found the advantages of this work: (1) the experimental conditions are relatively mild; (2) the catalyst Pt-Nb/MOR is economical; (3) the monomer yield of the target product is satisfactory and the separation of the product was simple. Furthermore, birch lignin was used to test the stability of the 2Pt-2Nb catalyst and it showed a good result (Fig. 6 ). The total monomer molar yield decreased from 147% to 130% and the cycloalkanes yield decreased from 122% to 106% during the third reuse. The catalyst was characterized after three cycles (Table 3 ), the variation of the metal content of Pt (1.7 wt% to 1.5 wt%) and Nb (2.1 wt% to 2.0 wt%) was within the margin of error. The specific surface area and pore volume of BET were almost the same as that of fresh catalysts, and the dispersion was slightly reduced (30.5% to 27.1%). The molecular sieve structure did not change significantly from XRD analysis (Fig. S4) and the average particle size of Pt was 3.9 nm, no obvious growth (Fig. 7, Fig. S5). The XPS (Fig. S6) showed that after three cycles, the signal of Pt 4d on the 2Pt-2Nb surface shifted 0.5 eV to the high binding energy, and the Pt species on the surface slightly favored the oxidation state, but still dominated the metal state. In addition, the total acid amounts of catalyst measured by Py-IR decreased from 702 to 605 μmol/g which may be one of the reasons for the decrease of monomer yield (Fig. S7, Table S5). Thermogravimetric analysis (Fig. S8) showed that the catalyst after three cycles had a weight loss at 350 °C, indicating that there may be severe coking on the catalyst, resulting in a decrease in monomer yield. After three times, the catalyst was regenerated by calcination in air at 400 °C for 4 h and reduction at 400 °C for 2 h (10% H2/Ar), the monomer yield over the refresh catalyst restored to 145%, indicating the regeneration possible. 3.4 Characterization of catalysts The X-ray diffraction patterns of MOR, 2Pt and 2Pt-2Nb were illustrated in Fig. S9. The diffraction peaks of Pt or Nb2O5 were not observed, which may be related to the low loading amounts (~2%). The TEM images in Figs. 7(a) and (c) showed the particle-size distributions of Pt in 2Pt and 2Pt-2Nb catalysts, which were 3.6 and 3.8 nm respectively. The high resolution TEM image in Fig. 7(b) showed lattice fringes with distances of 0.23 and 0.19 nm over 2Pt catalyst, consistent with the lattice spacing of Pt (111) and Pt (200), respectively. Lattice fringes with a spacing of 0.23 nm were also observed over 2Pt-2Nb, corresponding to the Pt (111) lattice spacing. Additionally, the lattice fringes at 0.32 and 0.29 nm were found and identified to the (001) and (030) planes of Nb2O5 crystals (Fig. 7(d)). The aforementioned results indicated that Nb was likely to exist in its oxidized form and Pt in metallic form. ICP analysis showed that the actual Pt loadings in 2Pt and 2Pt-2Nb were both 1.7 wt% and the content of Nb in 2Pt-2Nb was 2.1% (Table 3), within a reasonable margin of error. The BET surface areas of MOR, 2Pt and 2Pt-2Nb were determined along with the pore volume and sizes (Table 3). It is found that the BET surface area and total pore volume was decreased after Pt and Nb loadings. The dispersions of Pt were measured at 32.9% for 2Pt catalyst and 30.5% for 2Pt-2Nb, by CO pulse titration (Table 3). The XPS spectra of Pt 4d 5/2 in Fig. 8(a) showed the electronic states on two catalysts. It shows that Pt was existed in metallic state on both 2Pt and 2Pt-2Nb catalysts, the binding energy of Pt0 on 2Pt was 314.4 eV, while on 2Pt-2Nb was 313.7 eV, shifted to lower binding energy. The results of CO-DRIFT (Fig. 8(b)) also showed the linearly adsorbed CO on Pt0 species [Pt0-CO] [43] at 2066.7 cm–1 on 2Pt catalyst, while the peak was shifted towards low wavenumber to 2063.5 cm–1 on 2Pt-2Nb. Both results demonstrated that Pt exists in more metallic state on 2Pt-2Nb catalyst, which might be more advantageous in activating hydrogen. So, the measurement of reaction orders was carried out and found a zero-order reaction of H2 over 2Pt-2Nb catalyst was obtained (Fig. 9(a) ), while a first-order reaction of H2 over 2Pt catalyst was detected (Fig. 9(c)) when using bicyclohexane as the substrate, indicating that the activation of H2 on 2Pt-2Nb catalyst is much better than that on 2Pt catalyst. For substrate bicyclohexane, a first-order reaction was shown on both 2Pt and 2Pt-2Nb catalysts without significant difference (Figs. 9 (b) and (d)). The experimental results of kinetic isotope effect also proved the above conclusion (Fig. S10). The k H/k D= 2.6 over 2Pt catalyst, while k H/k D = 1.3 over 2Pt-2Nb. In the cleavage of C–C bong, the acidity plays another important role beside H2 activation, so, the types and relative contents of acid sites on the catalysts were detected using pyridine (Py) as probe molecular (Fig. 10 and Table S5). MOR, 2Pt and 2Pt-2Nb all have Lewis and Brönsted acids. The bands at 1445 and 1542 cm–1 were assigned to Lewis and Brönsted acid sites, respectively, and the bands at 1489 cm–1 were contributed by both Lewis and the Brönsted acid sites [44]. The total acid amount of MOR zeolite was 769.6 μmol/g, in which the ratio of B/L was 1.9. The total acid amount of 2Pt catalyst was decreased to 664.4 μmol/g, while the total acid amount of 2Pt-2Nb catalyst reached 1124.6 μmol/g. The increased acid amount of 2Pt-2Nb was come from the contribution of Nb2O5 and enhanced the performance in the activation and cracking of C–C bonds. Previous studies demonstrated the role of Nb2O5 and NbOPO4 in the activation of C–C bonds. 4 Conclusions In summary, we prepared economical Pt-Nb/MOR catalyst to facilitate the lignin depolymerization process into alky-cycloalkanes. Under the interaction of Pt and NbO x species in catalysts, the efficient C–C bonds cleavage of birch lignin allowed us to obtain 147% yield of monomer products. At the same time, a variety of lignin and model compounds were chosen as substrates and ideal monomer yields were all obtained, which proved that the 2Pt-2Nb/MOR catalyst had good universality. In the reaction of the model compound o-Phenyl Phenol, we found there was a C sp3–C sp3 cleavage pathway on this catalyst which was different from the previous one over NbO x -based catalysts. Bicyclohexane usually exists as a side product in the traditional NbO x -based catalytic system, however, it existed as an important intermediate in this system. The problem of monomer- product-decrease caused by the failure to break C sp3–C sp3 bonds on NbO x -based catalysts was solved. As a rate-determined step, the breaking of C sp3–C sp3 bonds of bicyclohexane was greatly promoted by the Pt-NbO x interaction. The catalyst characterization and kinetic studies showed that the interaction of Pt and NbO x changed the surface metal state, and more metallic Pt in 2Pt-2Nb/MOR made H2 dissociation easier. Meanwhile, the doping of NbO x provided more acid site, which was also an important factor to promote C sp3–C sp3 bonds breaking. In addition, the catalyst maintained good stability even after three cycles. Coking was the cause of a slight decrease in activity, which can be removed by calcination, and the regenerated catalyst has the same activity as the fresh one. In this work, economical catalysts were designed and different mainly reaction pathway from previous studies was proposed, which provided enlightenment for the design of lignin depolymerization catalysts. coredata.dc:description: The efficient conversion of lignin into mono-cycloalkanes via both C–O and C–C bonds cleavage are attractive, but challenging due to the high C–C bond dissociation energy. Previous studies have demonstrated that NbO x -based catalysts exhibited exceptional capabilities for CAr–C bond cleavage and broken the limitation of lignin monomers. In this work, we presented an economical multifunctional Pt-Nb/MOR catalyst that achieved an impressive monomer yield of 147% during the depolymerization and hydrodeoxygenation of lignin into mono-cycloalkanes. Reaction pathway studies showed that unlike traditional NbO x -based catalytic system, bicyclohexane was an important intermediate in this system and followed the C sp3–C sp3 cleavage pathway after complete cyclic-hydrogenation. Deep investigations demonstrated that the doping of Nb in Pt/MOR not only enhanced the activation of hydrogen by Pt, but also increased the acidity of MOR, both of these are favor for the hydrogenolytic cleavage of C sp3–C sp3 bonds. This work provides a low-cost catalyst to obtain high-yield monomers from lignin under relatively mild conditions and would help to design catalysts with higher activity for the valorization of lignin.
